comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Did somebody mention my name?  I was not AWOL but very much on AL I'll have you know.  The forage caps for the police were actually introduced in the early 1900's but the helmets were worn right up to the war of Independence.  During the 1913 lockout RIC officers drafted in to support the DMP wore both so it would not be easy to fix the time by the forage caps being worn here.  Does the "sentry" have a rifle at all?  I cannot see the barrel over his shoulder and as this was the training depot it may have been a swagger stick being carried in the right hand?  Our friends in the Garda Museum might be in a position to help on that.

comment._content: If this is the main gate of GHQ, then I'm pretty sure the gate lodge is still on the left. Streetview agrees - maps.google.ie/?ll=53.35356,-6.301973&spn=0.001241,0.... I don't think it is scan reversed. Looking at the chap on the left, his whistle chain can clearly be seen going into the pocket on his left, wear it is notmally worn (over his heart!). Looking at his right shoulder, there seems to be a fold, suggesting the "rifle" might be the strap of some rasonably heavy item, causing the material on his shoulder to gather. As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] says, you can't see a rifle barrel poking over his shoulder.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] You are correct Joe but Carol had made the correction early in the process so what you and I saw when we first saw it was the Depot as it is!  At that time the RIC did carry rifles and I believe that the general issue rifle was the Lee-Enfield Mark II which had a very stubby muzzle, it may be below the line of the shoulder but given how tight the strap appears to be I would expect that the barrel would appear above his shoulder.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Between 1904 and 1920 the R.I.C. were issued with Lee Enfield MK I and Lee Metford carbines with barrel lenghts of  21 inches, the long version of these rifles were about 30 inches which might explain why the rifle barrel is not visible in the photo.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08/] Thank you for the correction, I didn't realise that they had a shorter barrelled version of the rifles.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I think its very difficult to give a precise date on the photo, as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39191857@N05] said the headgear shown was worn from the early 1900's up until 1922 alongside the police helmets which incidentally survived into the early years of the Garda Siochana. The rifle is not much help either as we cant see exactly what it is, the constabulary had carbines of several varieties from their very early days. I would guess from the look of the photo it is early 1900's maybe around 1910 or a little earlier, the constables look a little too relaxed for it to be around 1920 I think.
